title: Harry Triguboff calls banks too 'restrictive' on lending
text:
He brushed aside a question about whether there was enough buyer support for continued new construction, saying he could afford to hold stock.

"I like to keep probably half anyway," he said. "I’m in no hurry to sell."

Meriton has traditionally held a large number of apartments for rent and for use as serviced apartments. The company's most recent financial report filed with corporate regulator ASIC, for the year to June 2018, reported a 5.4 per cent increase in the number of its investment units to 8255 from 7828 a year earlier.

The report also showed a drop in Meriton's operating profit after tax for the 2018 year from $384.3 million to $340.4 million.

Mr Triguboff, who has been a critic of state and local authorities' planning processes, said he was building as fast as councils would approve his plans.

"As soon as they approve, I build," he said. "It’s very difficult to get approvals."

However, he said some councils in Sydney had softened their resistance to projects and had become more willing to approve applications in a softer development market. This was part of what drove Meriton's increase in dwelling commencements last year, he said.

Advertisement

“Planning departments in councils have become more accommodating, which has allowed us to get projects under way more quickly," he said.

“The helpful attitude of planners means we can buy sites confident that we are not going to be bogged down for two or three years by the approvals process and all the while meeting holding costs."

Mr Triguboff also said this week's quarter-point rate cut needed to be repeated.

"If it is one-quarter and it’s followed by another one-quarter and another one-quarter, then it changes [things]," he said. "On its own, it’s not doing much. I would like them to cut more."
description: Rich Lister and developer says local councils are being more accommodating in a weaker market.
